he extended to the novel (Roman), or “romantic book,” the privilege that had traditionally been poetry’s, or allowed the novel a “higher unity” than the kind of book in which, as Goethe had put it in Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship

chiefly sentiments and events are exhibited.” Melville read Goethe’s romantic novel while writing Moby-​Dick, and his close reading of key works of romantic literature and criticism is well documented
